Fields.DialogueText: Leningrad, do you know what-- Wait, what's all this?
What's all what?
Where did you get all of these books?
These are the ship's books. They're all old, and musty, and really, very dry, but when you have to read, you have to read.
Read? You're planning on reading all of them?
Of course. What else am I supposed to do to keep myself entertained?

Fields.MenuText: If reading makes you happy, then by all means, Leningrad, read away.
Lending a hand on deck would be a great start. You are a member of the crew, after all.
Oh, so you're an egghead, then.

Fields.DialogueText: As if I needed your permission.
Ho ho, is that so? I'd be willing to argue that point!
I've been known to crack a few eggs, from time to time.
Excuse me?
Calm down. Anyway, it's good that you tracked me down - I've been meaning to speak with you. See, I need more books. These won't last me long.
No, I'm sorry, Leningrad, but I can't justify the funds right now just because you might run out of things to read. Maybe in a few months. Now, there's the alarm, let's go.
Just wait, Kapitan. I always get what I want eventually.
@BATTLE
We have enemies approaching, Kapitan!
Stations, everyone!
Kapitan, I was wondering - how many people died during the Swiss Sonderbundskrieg?
W-what? Good grief, not right now, Leningrad. We have Morganas inbound.
@BATTLE
All right, Leningrad. That was the fifteenth question you've asked me today. You're up to something, aren't you?
Up to something? I would never. I'm simply an inquisitive person.
Of course, if I had the books on my list, I wouldn't have to bombard you with this endless stream of questions...

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry, Leningrad, but I told you, not right now.
You're testing my patience.
You think you can annoy me into ordering your books? Good luck with that.

Fields.DialogueText: Not now, but soon enough.
Unfortunately, this test has just begun.
Rest assured, Kapitan - I don't need luck.
You will find, Leningrad, that I'm not so easily manipulated.
*BELL*
Well, hello there, Kapitan! Time to rise and shine!

Fields.MenuText: Oh, good grief, Leningrad! You nearly gave me a heart attack!
What time is it? Status report, Leningrad!
If you've woken me up for any other reason than the ship being on fire, I will end you.

Fields.DialogueText: Nonsense, your ticker isn't about to give out after a scare so small.
Time for you to buy a watch! Ah, but we don't have the money for a watch, do we? Or for books...
Ho ho, I'd like to see you try!
Anyway, I really do apologize for waking you - you did look so very relaxed, lying there. Like a little, stern baby.
But I just needed to know... Which French king was overthrown in the Revolution of 1848?
No, that's not going to work! Get out of here!
Also, I figured you'd want to know Morganas were close by...
Oh, honestly!
@BATTLE
Leningrad, to your station. And after that... We're going to have a discussion.
Whatever you say, Kapitan. See you in a bit.
@BATTLE
Leningrad, why did one of my officers ask me for the name of the revolt Tanzania led against Germany in 1907?
As it turns out, several of them were very interested in the questions I wanted answered. How sweet of them to ask you for me!
Be straight with me, Leningrad. How many?
Whatever do you mean?
How many of my officers have you convinced to annoy me for the foreseeable future?
Dozens of them to be honest. And considering the number of questions I have, this could continue for... months? Years, perhaps?

Fields.MenuText: All right, all right. I'll put in an order for your books.
While I'm fully aware that I should not give into you, I can't have my crew neglecting their duties because of your bad influence. I will get you your books.
Fine, I'll get your books. Also, you're terrible.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, isn't that just so kind of you, Kapitan?
What an admirably adept mind you have, Kapitan.
You can call me whatever name you please, provided I get my books.
Do not try anything like this again, Leningrad.
Vihollisia etelään.
Ymmärrän.
Leningrad, were you just speaking in Finnish?
Yes! I'm out of practice, but Officer Halko's fluent – his grandfather was from Finland. He was helping me practice while I wait for my books to arrive.

Fields.MenuText: Finnish is a difficult language - how many others do you speak?
I'll keep that in mind should we have a Finnish diplomat on board in the future.
Honestly, I'm surprised you have the discipline necessary to learn another language at all.

Fields.DialogueText: At last count, Russian, French, German, Swedish, English, and the aforementioned Finnish. I prefer reading books in their original languages.
You might want to rethink that. Diplomacy and I don't often mix well.
I'm surprised you have the discipline necessary to string words together into a coherent sentence, but surprises are everywhere, aren't they?
Moving onto another subject - how long until your books arrive?
It won't be much longer now. I've been keeping watch for days. Or, at least, it's seemed like days - I honestly have no idea how much time has passed.
You're really excited, aren't you? I mean, you're jumping up and down - I figure that's Leningrad-code for excited.
Why wouldn't I be excited? There's so much to learn, so much knowledge that I can use. It's exhilarating.
Oh, I almost forgot to tell you - Officer Halko said there's a Morgana approaching from the south.
That would have been useful information to have earlier.
@BATTLE
That's... a veritable mountain of books you have there, Leningrad. I mean, it actually goes from floor to ceiling. How much money did you make me spend, again?
Who cares about the cost? Look at it. It's so beautiful. *sniffle*
Leningrad... Are you crying?
Shut up, I am not.
All right, all right.
Now here, I have a present for you. You better like it.
It's... one of your books.
There are several in here that I think will be helpful to you, although... Finding them might be difficult. In the meantime, you should read the inscription on the inside.
"It is one of the blessings of old friends that you can afford to be stupid with them."
Oh, sorry! Wrong book, that's for Officer Halko. Here, this one is for you.
"Some books leave us free and some books make us free."

Fields.MenuText: This quote is much more in line with what I expected from you.
A book on philosophy and its impact on warfare? It should be an interesting read, Leningrad.
What's a Bolshevik like you doing quoting Emerson?

Fields.DialogueText: I figured you would think as much.
I've read it three times already - it's excellent.
I can be a Bolshevik and appreciate poets from all parts of the world, thank you very much.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm - we should get going. But, thank you for the book. I'll make good use of it, I promise.
I'm always happy to give books to people who will appreciate them!
@BATTLE
Why the serious face, Kapitan? You didn't lose the book I gave you, did you? I don't take kindly to people who lose books.
No, I didn't lose your book. It's just... Well, the crew has seemed especially tense, recently. It's been too long since we've had a break.
I've been considering ways to loosen them up.
You want the crew loosened up? Oh, don't worry, I'll take care of everything.

Fields.MenuText: Wait! Wait! Leningrad, I appreciate your enthusiasm, but just... Wait!
Before you take care of anything, you'll run your plan past me first.
I never thought the words "I'll take care of everything" would one day send a chill down my spine, but, here we are.

Fields.DialogueText: Why? You realize I'm actually offering to help out, right? I figured you would be thrilled.
I'm offering to help loosen up the crew. Not steal the queen's jewels.
Oh, you are so dramatic sometimes, aren't you?
Surely you understand my hesitation. You like to cause trouble, and you know it.
I'm not out to cause trouble this time - I like the crew, and I want to help out. I'll take care of them and you... well, you can take care of the Morganas that are northeast of us.
Convenient timing.
@BATTLE
Leningrad, what's going on? Why are all the officers so quiet? And why do they have such odd looks on their faces?
Don't worry. I just asked them if they thought their own experience of consciousness was the same as everyone else's. They've been considering the question for some time now.

Fields.MenuText: You... You asked them... What now?
When I told you to run your plan past me earlier, this was why.
How is that loosening up the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: You don't really want me to repeat the question, do you?
This was why? Oh, the horror of grown men and women using their brains to consider complex matters.
Well, if you'll calm down for two seconds, I'll tell you.
Tension often occurs because the mind is stagnant. The crew has been going through the same motions for days, and the repetition is wearing on them.
I have little ability to alter their day to day duties, but I can give them new ideas to consider. I know that when I'm stressed, a new idea always makes me feel better.
So, this is you... helping. No tricks? No troublemaking?
No tricks, no troublemaking. I know it's unorthodox, but, then again, most of the things I do are unorthodox.
All right, continue on then. Just... Don't let it get out of hand.
Captain, enemies are approaching!
Not to fear, Kapitan. I'll keep everything under control.
@BATTLE
Leningrad, two of my officers just got into a fight.
Was it Cabrera and Lee? They really need to put their unresolved feelings to rest.
No, it was not Cabrera and Lee. It was Nyugen and Schneider.
Nyugen and Schneider have unresolved feelings? Oh, I did not see that coming.
No, Leningrad. Nyugen and Schneider do not have unresolved feelings. Or at least they didn't... until now.
Then why did they fight?
They fought because you asked them who defines good and evil, and they have very different views on the subject.
Oh. That's not good.

Fields.MenuText: I trusted that you wouldn't cause trouble.
Your antics have endangered the well-being of my crew.
You think? I knew you wouldn't be able to resist stirring the pot!

Fields.DialogueText: You see me as the troublemaker? I was trying to help!
If a pinch of philosophy rattled them so much, I doubt they had much "well-being" before I interfered.
Stirring the pot? I'm trying to keep the pot from boiling over, Kapitan!
Nyet! You can't blame this on me. I wasn't trying to provoke them! And regardless of whether or not I was - Nyugen and Schneider are adults, responsible for their own actions!
Make all the excuses you want, Leningrad. I have enough trouble with the Morganas, I can't deal with your brand of trouble as well. Go read your books and leave the crew alone.
Captain, enemies approaching!
Like I said.
@BATTLE
Leningrad? Are you in here? All I see are books. Wait, why are there two mountains now? Have they multiplied?
Can I help you, Kapitan?
I wanted to apologize.
Why? Because the crew is getting tense without me there entertaining them?

Fields.MenuText: I was wrong to so readily dismiss the work you were doing.
It appears your philosophical questions were a greater source of amusement for the crew than I realized.
Unbelievably, yes.

Fields.DialogueText: But, even more than that, I was wrong to speak to you the way I did. You are right. Nyugen and Schneider are adults, and solely responsible for their actions.
I allowed my frustration with them to color my conversation with you, and I'm sorry. Will you forgive me?
Da, of course. I realize that I could have used more discernment in choosing my questions for the crew. So... I'm sorry too.
Well, I'll give it some thought after we take care of the Morganas west of us.
@BATTLE
Have you done something different with your hair today, Kapitan? You're looking especially sharp.
If you want something, just go ahead and ask me, Leningrad.
Well, I do think your hair looks nice. But I would like it if you'd consider ordering the things on this list. It's just a few music records.
What is on this list? More books?
I was thinking of organizing some sort of evening activity for everyone. I figure that would be as non-controversial an activity as they come.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like an excellent idea, Leningrad.
As long as it doesn't distract from the crew's duties, I'll sign off on the order.
Considering how well things went the last time I tried to refuse you, I wouldn't dare try to do so again.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you think so!
As long as Nguyen and Schneider don't have another one of their tiffs, I think we'll be all right.
That's the sort of defeatist attitude I like to hear, Kapitan!
Nothing too Bolshevik in nature, okay?
As entertaining as that would be, I promise I'll remain as behaved as I'm capable of being.
Thank you. Now, that's the alarm, we need to get to our stations. But I'll put in the order later today.
@BATTLE
Officer, have you seen Leningrad?
Last I saw, she had just gone into the mess hall, sir.
What?
Really - I saw her slip in after the last meal.
Leningrad? Leningrad! Are you in there?
Well, hello there, Kapitan. What are you up to?
I had wanted to check and see whether you'd received your music. But now, I'm really more interested to hear why you've holed up in the mess hall.
I did receive the music! Spasibo, Kapitan, for ordering it, by the way. As for your other question... I'd appreciate it if you decided to wait and see.

Fields.MenuText: I'm going to trust you with this, Leningrad. Please, don't disappoint me.
As long as you don't prevent the crew from eating their next meal, I suppose I can wait.
Maybe I can extract you from here somehow.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, da, I know.
Oh, I would never stand between someone and food.
Maybe you shouldn't announce your plans while you're standing right in front of me.
*ALARM*
Captain, Morgana fleet headed our way!
Don't worry, Kapitan. I give you my word that everything will be fine.
That's reassuring.
@BATTLE
Leningrad, when you said you were going to organize an evening activity, I was expecting some sort of concert. Not a dance. I certainly wasn't expecting a swing dance.
What, you don't like it? Look at how happy all the officers seem. Some of them are much lighter on their feet than I would have assumed.
You're not wrong. I must admit, the mess hall looks great. I'm not sure where you dug up the decorations you used, but it was an excellent effort on your part.
Spasibo, Kapitan.
Although, I am curious - where did you get the phonograph?
Officer Halko had a wind-up one onboard. It puts out more sound than I would have thought, too.
Who brings a wind-up phonograph on a naval vessel?
Someone who thinks ahead, obviously.

Fields.MenuText: It does display an admirable amount of forethought, I'll give him that.
Are you sure bringing said phonograph aboard this ship is permissible?
You are quite attached to Officer Halko, aren't you?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm always so amused to find out what random objects the crew brings onboard.
Shall we talk about whose ship this really is, Kapitan? You might hold the title, but it's my name on the side.
He understands me. You'll understand that there aren't many people on this planet I can say that about.
Damn! There are Morganas nearby. They always ruin everything...
You're sure?
Da. I sense them.
All right. Get to your station. I'll sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
That's an angry look you have on your face.
Look at this!
A newspaper article? Morganas attacked ships at the Zhdanov Shipyard in Leningrad. Ah, isn't that...
The place of my birth? Da, it is. Figuratively speaking, of course.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry, Leningrad. I understand how upsetting that must be.
You can't allow your anger to cloud your judgement in battle, Leningrad.
Out of curiosity, where was the literal place of your birth? Were you... born?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I appreciate your understanding.
And I thought I had difficulty sympathizing with others!
Stay focused on the current subject, Kapitan!
It's one thing when the Morganas attack us. I'm a destroyer, I'm meant to fight. Not all of the ships in that shipyard were meant for warfare.
And then, the Morganas just go in and take advantage of those who can't stand up to them. Boils my Soviet blood. Again, figuratively speaking.
Planning on doing something about it?
I'm planning on doing something...
I'll continue planning once we've fought the Morganas approaching us.
@BATTLE
"Oh, Captain! My Captain!"
You do know who that was written about, don't you?
Really, I'm just surprised that you know any poetry at all. Although, you know, I think you could look quite sharp in one of those stovepipe hats...
Captain, enemies spotted!
We'll continue this delightful conversation at a later time, Leningrad.
@BATTLE
So, what was it that you wanted?
No one knows revolution like I do, right? I was thinking maybe that's what the Morganas are doing here.
Okay...
I mean, what is a revolution, if not an uprising against those currently in power? But, here's the thing, revolutions don't happen for no reason.
There has to be some sort of impetus. If we could figure out the Morganas' motivation...
... then that might help us determine what they're planning next. The only problem is, they haven't proven to be very communicative.
True. But I know all the reasons why a revolution might occur. I think, if I had the chance to speak to them, I might be able to piece the solution together.
Any Morganas in particular?
I think I'll have the greatest chance of success with the battleships. Treason, Sabotage, and Sedition must have some underlying reasoning behind their attacks.
If anyone was to have an idea of motivation, a need for it, it would be them. So, what do you say? Can I try?
For now... I say all right.
Leningrad, what is that?
It's an electrical audio recorder. Officer Halko had it onboard. He said I could use it to record my conversations with the Morganas. Nifty, huh?

Fields.MenuText: Can I try it?
How on earth did Officer Halko manage to smuggle so much technology on board?
I'm not sure that I trust you with that sort of technology. I can imagine all sorts of unethical ways you might put it to use.

Fields.DialogueText: You'll have to ask Officer Halko's permission. Nyet, I'm only kidding. You can use it.
He's quite capable, that one.
Oh, I know. I've been brainstorming.
These Morganas won't stand a chance against me. You just wait and see, Kapitan. I do always succeed, eventually.
Captain! It's Treason and her fleet, just south of us!
Time to put this recorder to good use.
We'll subdue them, first. Then, you'll have a chance to communicate with her.
@BATTLE
Treason! Wait, I want to talk to you. Just for a moment.
I just want to understand why you're doing what you're doing.
Treason, wait!
Stop, Leningrad. You can't make her cooperate.
You sure? I am a Bolshevik, so violence isn't out of the realm of possibility.
Leningrad...
Fine... she gets away this time...
(Speaks in foreign language)
Leningrad, I can hardly believe my eyes! You've organized your mountains of books into mere skyscrapers.
Although, I must say, I'm having difficulty pinpointing your method of organization...
My method is typically madness, Kapitan. Or the other way around - hawks and handsaws, you understand.
While my discussion with Treason, that antisocial nut of a Morgana, wasn't a success, there is still research I can do.
Such as...?
Like, identifying possible philosophies to which the Morganas could ascribe. Fanaticism, collectivism, you know? And rejecting others like, I don't know, hedonism, obviously.
Well?

Fields.MenuText: Are you all right, Leningrad?
You're not getting in over your head, are you? I have a responsibility to look after my crew - which includes you.
If I was wondering something, I forgot it the moment you hurled terms like collectivism and hedonism my way. That was... a bit much.

Fields.DialogueText: What do mean? Of course I'm all right.
I've never been in over my head in the whole of my life, Kapitan.
Oh, they are not even that difficult. If you want difficult, let's talk about reductionism. Ontological, theoretical, methodological - you like Occam's Razor, right?
Oh, there are Morganas headed this way. I guess I'll have to save my research for later.
Okay... Um... Good talk, Leningrad...
@BATTLE
Hey, there's Leningrad! I haven't seen her outside of her study in a while.
Not at all? I thought she thrived on teasing the crew?
Not since we fought Treason. She's kept to herself. Which, when you consider who we're talking about, is more than a little out of the ordinary.
I can't even remember the last time I saw her eat.
That's not good.
Leningrad? I was just about to head over to the mess hall - you want to come?
I need my crew healthy, Leningrad. Come on, we're going to go get you some food.
Hot dog eating contest in five minutes, Leningrad - come on!
Hmm? Sorry, not now, Kapitan. I have more research to do.
Actually nevermind, there are Morganas to the northwest of us.
All right, thanks, Leningrad.
@BATTLE
When was the last time you left your study, Leningrad? You're looking kind of pale.
I'm a Soviet. Paleness comes with the territory.
Be that as it may...

Fields.MenuText: ... I'm a little worried about you.
... the rest of the crew is worried about you.
... with you cooped up in here, it's far quieter than it is normally. I don't like it, it's eerie.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate your concern, Kapitan.
The crew can tolerate my absence for a little while.
I'll have Officer Halko lend you his phonograph.
Listen, I'm making progress. At least, I think I'm making progress. Relatively sure. I've narrowed down the Morganas' possible philosophies quite a bit.
If I could just understand them a little, that might be all I need to crack this entire thing open.
That's the alarm. Leningrad, just... take care of yourself, okay?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Aye aye, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
After we take care of this, I suppose!
Leningrad, is that...?
It's Sabotage. It's about time she showed up. Deal with her group. Then, she's mine.
@BATTLE
(Speaks in foreign language)
Are you in more of a talkative mood than Treason was?
If you're just here to mess with my head, then be on your way. I don't have the time or energy to deal with your brand of entertainment.
(Speaks in foreign language)

Fields.MenuText: Leningrad, should I be worried?

Fields.DialogueText: She's all talk. Well, she's all... whatever that is.

Fields.MenuText: Can you translate that?
That sound is strange.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't make heads or tails of it, Kapitan.
I know my way around a lot of languages, Kapitan.
And?
I'm not even sure it's a language.
And now she's slipping away. Slow the engines, Leningrad. We'll only waste fuel trying to catch her now.
Aye aye, Kapitan.
How's your research coming, Leningrad?
Fine.
Okay.
Leningrad, I was wondering - were you able to decipher anything Sabotage said?
Nyet, but I felt a strange sensation try to overwhelm me. Almost a push to incite rebellion, against... against you.

Fields.MenuText: From what I've seen, I really don't think you're that susceptible.
Should I be concerned?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not. I would be offended if you thought otherwise.
I'd like to think I have a strong enough grasp on morality and human rights that you needn't worry.
She can try whatever she wants, as long as I'm able to get clues concerning the Morganas' motivation.
Captain, we have enemies approaching.
All right, I'm coming.
@BATTLE
Like an attempt at mind control...
Leningrad! I'm surprised to see you made it to today's dance.
Officer Halko convinced me to come out. At least for a half hour. Otherwise, he said he'd burn my books. I wouldn't put it past him, he's a bit of a pyro.

Fields.MenuText: Well, that was good of him.
A smuggler and a pyromaniac? What an impressive resume he's building.
I know I've seen Halko with my own eyes, but the more you describe him, the less I think he's a real person.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so.
Oh, you should hear some of his other extracurriculars.
I'm pretty sure that's what most people think of Finns.
When was the last time you slept? I don't generally condone telling people they look awful, but Leningrad - you look awful.
No time for sleep, not right now. I need to be prepared.
I'll take care of my own needs once I make some good progress.
Sir, we have Morganas headed this way.
Understood. Come on, Leningrad, let me help you get to your station.
@BATTLE
Leningrad, what are you doing out here in the cold?
I hardly feel it.
You're shivering.
Am I? Well then, give me your coat.
Here you go. I'm getting you your own coat, next time we go to port. The most garish one I can find.
Leningrad?
Another Morgana is coming for us.

Fields.MenuText: You sense them?
You can't possibly know that.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan, I do.
You doubt my abilities, Kapitan?
You're putting so much pressure on yourself right now. I know how much this means to you, determining the Morganas' motivation, protecting others from their attacks...
I don't want you getting your hopes up. I know you said you always succeed, but what if this time you don't?
There are the Morganas. Can you see them, out there on the horizon? I'll sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
There's Sedition! Let's subdue her like all the others.
Leningrad!
(Speaks foreign language)
Your mind control won't work on me. I will not relent. Tell me why the Morganas are doing what they're doing! What possible motivation could you have?
Leningrad...

Fields.MenuText: Mind control check...
Remember where your loyalties lie, Leningrad.
Sedition is no match for you, Leningrad.

Fields.DialogueText: (Speaks more angrily)
Okay, I think that's enough. Kapitan, let's shut her up.
With pleasure.
@BATTLE
Let her think she is. The more she talks, the more information I have.
Considering your love of books, Leningrad, I'm surprised you would throw them across the room.
I needed something to beat senseless. They'll forgive me eventually.
Sedition's one of the nastier Morganas I've encountered.
There are some choice Russian words I'll throw her way the next time I see her.
Leningrad...

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for not turning your back on me.
The dedication you showed to your Captain and crew was admirable.
I give you my word to personally beat her senseless next time we see her, if that would make you feel better.

Fields.DialogueText: If I was going to pull a stunt like that, I would have done it long ago.
Well, I suppose I've grown to like you all, somewhat.
I'll sell tickets to the crew. It will be our next stress-relief night.
What are you thinking?
I failed. I tried my best, I put in the work - and I still failed. I have nothing to show for the many, many hours I spent working on this particular problem.
I've never failed at anything before. And I didn't just fail myself. I failed you, the crew, the...
Wait. Stop. Leningrad, I have no doubt that, someday, in the future, you will identify the Morganas' motivation. Not today, but someday, you will.
But...
Let me finish. Until that day comes, I need you at your best. Not this obsessive Leningrad who's been sulking around the ship, ignoring the crew members...
I do not sulk!
I need the revolution-loving, knowledge-sharing, people-entertaining Leningrad who makes this ship a better place.
You're getting sentimental, Kapitan. I don't do sentimentality.
All the same, are you still with me? You're going to be okay?
Takes more than the bombastic annoyance of a Morgana to shut me up.

Fields.MenuText: She's one of the strangest friends I've got.
Why... is my heart pounding? I don't have feelings for her. No. That would be insane. Definitely insane.
